page.title: 13Landscape around W.Bassett
page.content: The town of Wootton Bassett stands on a ridge of{Corallian Limestone}about 130 metres above sea level.To the west the built up area of the town stops at the top of the limestone{scarp slope.} In recent years the town has expanded down the more gentle{dip slope}to the east. Surrounding 'Wootton Bassett on the hill' are extensive vales of{Oxford} {Clay}and{Kimmeridge Clay.}This low and wet land is crossed by small streams such as the Brinkworth Brook draining towards the R.Avon. The clay{vales}have a rural landscape of scattered{dairy farms}surrounded by rough and managed grassland.Fields are divided by{hedgerows}which now contain many dead elm trees due to attacks of Dutch Elm Disease in the late 1970's. In places there are small patches of deciduous woodland.
